thread.title: Julie Bishop sees US-China fight as risk to Australian trade
thread.title_full: Julie Bishop sees US-China fight as risk to Australian trade | afr.com

author: John Kehoe
title: Julie Bishop sees US-China fight as risk to Australian trade
text:
"From Australia's perspective about two-thirds of our trade passes through the South China Sea." Trevor Collens Share on twitter Share on Google Plus by John Kehoe Foreign Affairs Minister Julie Bishop held emerged from talks with Secretary of State John Kerry to back the United States navy challenging China's territorial claims in the South China Sea, declaring that unimpeded passage through the huge international trade corridor is critical to Australia's national interest.
The US navy is preparing to conduct "freedom of navigation" operations near reefs and artificial islands that China claims as sovereign territory, but which smaller Asian neighbours contest ownership of.
After meeting Secretary Kerry at his Boston home on Monday and later dining alongside new Defence Minister Marise Payne and senior Pentagon officials, Ms Bishop said the "United States clearly wants to see as much freedom as possible in accordance with international law".
"Our interest is to have a freedom of navigation, a freedom of overflight, because from Australia's perspective about two-thirds of our trade passes through the South China Sea," Ms Bishop told The Australian Financial Review .
"These matters are exceedingly important to our national interest."
The US has been briefing its Asian allies on plans to conduct freedom of navigation patrols within 12 nautical miles of at least one of the disputed islands in the South China Sea, to challenge China's efforts to claim large parts of the waterway, The New York Times reported .
Any US naval exercise testing China's claimed sovereignty may escalate tensions between Beijing and Washington, and place the Turnbull government in an awkward position between its close security and economic partners.
James Brown, director of Alliance 21 at the United States Studies Centre in Sydney, said Australia and the US both want to stop Chinese militarisation of the artificial islands.
 "Both countries are having trouble changing Chinese behaviour," he said.
China has defiantly dredged reefs and built artificial islands across 1200 hectares around the Spratly archipelago since late 2013. The seven man-made outposts include a runway for aeroplanes and buildings to potentially hold military personnel and hardware.
Beijing has reclaimed 17 times as much space in two years than the other claimants in Vietnam, The Philippines, Malaysia, Taiwan and Brunei have reclaimed over the previous 40 years, the Pentagon has said.
Australia and the US do not take sides over who has sovereignty over the islands, arguing it should be determined by international law. They are concerned about China's aggressive and bullying conduct.
Rory Medcalf, head of the National Security College in Canberra, said Australian support for US freedom of navigation exercises would "send a strong signal of encouragement to other US partners and allies in the region".
The annual Australiaâ€“US Ministerial Consultations kicked off in Boston on Monday, including an inaugural meeting between US Defence Secretary Ashton Carter and Senator Payne.
Entering the main meeting on Tuesday, Ms Bishop intended to seek clarity from the Obama administration on ostensible overtures by Chinese President Xi Jinping during his visit to the White House last month.
"We will be seeking from the United States their read on President Xi Jinping's statement in Washington that China does not intend to militarize the claimed artificial reefs in the South China Sea," Ms Bishop said. "That was a significant statement that he made at the time of meeting President Obama."
Other topics on the AUSMIN agenda include military operations against Islamic State in Iraq and Syria, ongoing challenges in Afghanistan, relations with India and Japan, US marine forces in Darwin, the government's Defence White Paper and the Trans-Pacific Partnership.
At a working dinner in Boston on Monday night, other attendees included the chairman of the US Joint Chiefs of Staff Joseph Dunford, Australia's Ambassador in Washington Kim Beazley, US Ambassador in Canberra John Berry and Secretary of the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade Peter Varghese.
